commit_message:
Remove duplicated test cases

The class ServersControllerCreateTest has the following duplicated
test cases since I091f14a9753059d759ba2f7b05ff33f5abea0f00 :

 * test_create_instance_with_config_drive_disabled
 * test_create_instance_local_href
 * test_create_instance_admin_pass_empty
 * test_create_instance_invalid_personality
 * test_create_location

This patch removes the duplicated test cases.
In addition, this removes the bookhref of test_create_location() also,
because it is not used.

Change-Id: I218d5ff443d4dbcec7520eab0b42e77fbd30eba8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/77/51777/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def test_create_instance_with_config_drive_disabled(self): config_drive = [{'config_drive': 'foo'}] params = {'config_drive': config_drive} old_create = compute_api.API.create def create(*args, **kwargs): self.assertEqual(kwargs['config_drive'], None) return old_create(*args, **kwargs) self.stubs.Set(compute_api.API, 'create', create) self._test_create_extra(params) def test_create_instance_local_href(self): self.req.body = jsonutils.dumps(self.body) res = self.controller.create(self.req, self.body).obj server = res['server'] self.assertEqual(FAKE_UUID, server['id']) def test_create_instance_admin_pass_empty(self): self.body['server']['flavorRef'] = 3 self.body['server']['adminPass'] = '' self.req.body = jsonutils.dumps(self.body) # The fact that the action doesn't raise is enough validation self.controller.create(self.req, self.body) def test_create_instance_invalid_personality(self): def fake_create(*args, **kwargs): codec = 'utf8' content = 'b25zLiINCg0KLVJpY2hhcmQgQ$$%QQmFjaA==' start_position = 19 end_position = 20 msg = 'invalid start byte' raise UnicodeDecodeError(codec, content, start_position, end_position, msg) self.stubs.Set(compute_api.API, 'create', fake_create) self.body['server']['personality'] = [ { "path": "/etc/banner.txt", "contents": "b25zLiINCg0KLVJpY2hhcmQgQ$$%QQmFjaA==", }, ] self.req.body = jsonutils.dumps(self.body) self.assertRaises(webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest, self.controller.create, self.req, self.body) def test_create_location(self): selfhref = 'http://localhost/v2/fake/servers/%s' % FAKE_UUID bookhref = 'http://localhost/fake/servers/%s' % FAKE_UUID image_href = 'http://localhost/v2/images/%s' % self.image_uuid self.body['server']['imageRef'] = image_href self.req.body = jsonutils.dumps(self.body) robj = self.controller.create(self.req, self.body) self.assertEqual(robj['Location'], selfhref)

commit_message:
Add docs explaining what/how resume_volume_create works

Change-Id: I502ba91fe61a236b7643b9799d1cdbc1d1caeeb1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/42/52242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # INTRO: This examples shows how a hierachy of flows can be used to create a # pseudo-volume in a reliable & resumable manner using taskflow + a miniature # version of what cinder does while creating a volume (very miniature). # NOTE(harlowja): this is used to attempt to find a given logbook with # a given id and a given flow details inside that logbook, we need this # reference so that we can resume the correct flow (as a logbook tracks # flows and a flow detail tracks a individual flow). # # Without a reference to the logbook and the flow details in that logbook # we will not know exactly what we should resume and that would mean we # can't resume what we don't know. # If no 'tracking id' (think a fedex or ups tracking id) is provided then # we create one by creating a logbook (where flow details are stored) and # creating a flow detail (where flow and task state is stored). The # combination of these 2 objects unique ids (uuids) allows the users of # taskflow to reassociate the workflows that were potentially running (and # which may have partially completed) back with taskflow so that those # workflows can be resumed (or reverted) after a process/thread/engine # has failed in someway.

commit_message:
Fixes broken doc references

The references in configuringservices.rst did not resolve to
html addresses and were not referenced correctly in the browser.
This new fix will use the preferred way to cross reference documents.
Has the disadvantage that if the reference changes, it need to be
updated at severeal places in the document.

Change-Id: I3b8f71a95e66266b569aa1141985e47f1f4554c3
Closes-Bug: 1232878

commit_message:
Sync jsonutils from oslo

Synce the changes of jsonutils from oslo, following fixes are synced:

Ia915f3175bee370d747e362cd9d35d8536c1b7b2
Id1aa7af26b0f5d929337cc373c6a4f802bba2cec
Ic94f238a5f92f28ae1b6154fb56f00c4c9fa3283
I8b246f20f9001379fcb5ca3a84aabee3847cb945

Most of them are py33 fixes, and keystoneclient is required by a dozen of
projects, we should update it to avoid py33 issue in dependent projects.

Closes-Bug #1239602

Change-Id: I65c28896d1551fd537dd7774e87bc479a477a7ab

commit_message:
Adds more uniformity to identity update_user calls

 * It was not possible to change a user's name using the KVS driver.
 * The KVS driver was not filtering the user dict before handing it
   back to that caller.
 * Adds a test to the LDAP driver to explicitly show that changing a
   user's name is not allowed.

Related-Bug: #1214686
Change-Id: Ia0951a58ef09833849d3eb5e714c7efbd901f5c5

added_lines: def test_update_user_name(self): user = {'id': uuid.uuid4().hex, 'name': 'initial_name', 'enabled': True, 'domain_id': DEFAULT_DOMAIN_ID} self.identity_api.create_user(user['id'], user) user_ref = self.identity_api.get_user(user['id']) self.assertEqual(user['name'], user_ref['name']) user_ref['name'] = 'changed_name' updated_user = self.identity_api.update_user(user_ref['id'], user_ref) # NOTE(dstanek): the SQL backend adds an 'extra' field containing a # dictionary of the extra fields in addition to the # field on the object. For the details see: # SqlIdentity.test_update_project_returns_extra if 'extra' in updated_user: del updated_user['extra'] self.assertDictEqual(user_ref, updated_user) user_ref = self.identity_api.get_user(user_ref['id']) self.assertEqual(user_ref['name'], 'changed_name')

Use abstract base class for catalog driver

Use the abc module for managing abstract base classes in the driver
layer and add missing methods to concrete classes.

bp abstract-base-class-drivers

commit_message:
Replace mox with mox3

Mox3 is an unofficial port of the Google mox framework
(http://code.google.com/p/pymox/) to Python 3.
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/mox3

Align with global-requirement and update the importing clause.

Partial implement: blueprint py33-support

Change-Id: I3ce1748356c43b65ef81abefe67f777e915ba8e7

Initialize fallback ref

* devstack-vm-gate-wrap.sh: Set the fallback reference to an empty
string so it won't reuse a prior loop iteration's value.

Add an introduction to explain resume_many example

Change-Id: I162eff7b2988418f8dde9d89cd55c9095e72b40a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/40/52240/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # INTRO: In this example we create a common persistence database (sqlite based) # and then we run a few set of processes which themselves use this persistence # database, those processes 'crash' (in a simulated way) by exiting with a # system error exception. After this occurs a few times we then activate a # script which doesn't 'crash' and it will resume all the given engines flows # that did not complete. # # This shows how a set of tasks can be finished even after repeatingly being # crashed, *crash resistance* if you may call it, due to the engine concept as # well as the persistence layer which keeps track of the state a flow # transitions through and persists the intermediary inputs and outputs and # overall flow state.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/17/52217/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # INTRO: In this example we create two tasks, one that will say hi and one # that will say bye (with optional capability) to raise an error while # executing. During execution if a later task fails, the reverting that will # occur in the hi task will undo this (in a funny way). # # To also show the effect of task persistence we create a temporary database # that will track the state transitions of this hi + bye workflow, this # persistence allows for you to examine what is stored (using a sqlite client) # as well as shows you what happens during reversion and what happens to # the database during both of these modes (failing or not failing). def print_wrapped(text): print("-" * (len(text))) print(text) print("-" * (len(text))) # This generates your flow structure (at this stage nothing is ran).# Persist the flow and task state here, if the file exists already blowup # if not don't blowup, this allows a user to see both the modes and to # see what is stored in each case. # NOTE(harlowja): don't exist with non-zero status code, so that we can # print the book contents, as well as avoiding exiting also makes the # unit tests (which also runs these examples) pass.
deleted_lines: def print_wrapped(text): print("-" * (len(text))) print(text) print("-" * (len(text)))

Boost graph flow example comments

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/10/52210/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # In this example there are complex dependencies between tasks that are used to # perform a simple set of linear equations. # # As you will see below the tasks just define what they require as input # and produce as output (named values). Then the user doesn't care about # ordering the TASKS (in this case the tasks calculate pieces of the overall # equation). # # As you will notice graph_flow resolves dependencies automatically using the # tasks requirements and provided values and no ordering dependency has to be # manually created. # # Also notice that flows of any types can be nested into a graph_flow; subflows # dependencies will be resolved too!! Pretty cool right!# Provide the initial variable inputs using a storage dictionary.
deleted_lines: # In this example there are complex dependencies between # tasks. User shouldn't care about ordering the Tasks. # GraphFlow resolves dependencies automatically using tasks' # requirements and provided values. # Flows of any types can be nested into Graph flow. Subflows # dependencies will be resolved too.

commit_message:
Storwize: Fix iogrp availability check

Do not check if vdisk_count is greater than zero to determine iogrp
availability. This is wrong, and leads to the driver not being able to
use empty iogrps.

Added caching for NexentaStor appliance 'volroot' value.

added_lines: VERSION = '1.0.1' """Executes volume driver commands on Nexenta Appliance. Version history: 1.0.0 - Initial driver version. 1.0.1 - Added caching for NexentaStor appliance 'volroot' value. """ VERSION = VERSION conf = self.configuration self.nms_cache_volroot = conf.nexenta_nms_cache_volroot self._nms2volroot = {} # on disk. def _get_volroot(self, nms): if not self.nms_cache_volroot or nms not in self._nms2volroot: self._nms2volroot[nms] = nms.server.get_prop('volroot') return self._nms2volroot[nms] volroot = self._get_volroot(nms)
deleted_lines: import urlparseVERSION = '1.0.0' """Executes volume driver commands on Nexenta Appliance.""" # on disk volroot = nms.server.get_prop('volroot')

commit_message:
Fix to use proper random values

In several tests, they need int values but use rand_name().
Especially, test_security_group_rules.py has a potentially bug.
And, when we will change the rand_name() to return string value, the
errors will occur in others.
So this commit fixes it and belows:
 * just import the module instead of importing the function
 * minor comment typo

Change-Id: Ic957c741b9ad3631d726dc6cfb5ecb9e0077a884

commit_message:
Improve display of instance image information

When instance is booted from volume image it returns a string,
while for instance from image returns a dict. Fix is made to
handle both cases.

Change-Id: I23aeccd21f88a353222d3fc7dc4b5c337c2bfecb
Closes-Bug: #1239896

commit_message:
Add stack phases to extras.d handling

Add hooks to stack.sh, unstack.sh and clean.sh to call the extras.d
scripts at multiple points in stack.sh.  This allows these scripts to
perform installation and startup tasks at similar times as they would
if integrated into stack.sh.

extras.d/70-tempest.sh is present as an example of the structure
of these scripts.

See extras.d/README.md for more information.

Change-Id: Ic1fe522559b94d204d6c0319a2e3d23684c8d028
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/39/51939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Extras Source # -------------- # Phase: source if [[ -d $TOP_DIR/extras.d ]]; then for i in $TOP_DIR/extras.d/*.sh; do [[ -r $i ]] && source $i source done fi # Extras Install # -------------- # Phase: install if [[ -d $TOP_DIR/extras.d ]]; then for i in $TOP_DIR/extras.d/*.sh; do [[ -r $i ]] && source $i stack install done fi # Extras Configuration # ==================== # Phase: post-config if [[ -d $TOP_DIR/extras.d ]]; then for i in $TOP_DIR/extras.d/*.sh; do [[ -r $i ]] && source $i stack post-config done fi # Phase: extra [[ -r $i ]] && source $i stack extra
deleted_lines: [[ -r $i ]] && source $i stack

commit_message:
Removes unwanted mox and fixture files

Module ironic.openstack.commom.fixture.moxstubout and mockptch
are no longer needed, so the whole directory is removed by this
patch. mox is removed from test-requirements.txt because it is
no longer used in ironic unit test cases.

Change-Id: I6060546b565c096c3a602b22f28b5d84b8a03b24

commit_message:
Add neutron parallel job

This commit creates a new neutron tox job that runs the same tests as
a non-neutron tempest job except for those that don't currently work
with neutron enabled. This will be used for debugging neutron in
parallel since smoke doesn't actually run much.

Change-Id: Ie8388af63c4701492523c16aa991045c470b0e9f

commit_message:
Revert patch causing Instance Image Perf Issue

The previous patch https://review.openstack.org/52115 is causing
image get call for each instance. Reverting this back.

Fix will follow in another patch.

Related to bug: Bug: #1239896

Change-Id: If0d6feba50eb3f45248019fcc48580d1eae60d67
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/88/52188/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if hasattr(instance, 'image'): # Instance from image returns dict if isinstance(instance.image, dict): if instance.image.get('id') in image_map: instance.image = image_map[instance.image['id']] else: # Instance from volume returns a string instance.image = {'name': instance.image if instance.image else _("-")}
deleted_lines: if (hasattr(instance, 'image') and hasattr(instance.image, 'id') and instance.image['id'] in image_map): instance.image = image_map[instance.image['id']]

"}]
commit_message:
Remove general assumption in get_packages()

get_packages() always included 'general' as a default 'service' file.
Remove this assumption and add it explicitly to the primary package
installation call.  This allows get_package() to be used in other places
where 'general' is not desired to be included.

Change-Id: I1eed4386d073d6ae9534aedae32654208c6662e8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/38/49838/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Given the current precedence of configuration lookup, this patch should never have been accepted without code that also removes the paste_api configuration.


Revert "Removes unnecessary api-paste.ini configuration"

This reverts commit 3cf9a45458672862ce4e81a3ce45cd98112f93d4

commit_message:
xenapi: stop agent errors stopping build

We should still report agent errors, but they should not stop a server
from building, because that server still may be ready to use.

Once this change is in place, we can look to selectively add back in
certain errors that fail the build, as we decide what makes sense on a
case by case basis.

Fixes bug 1233548
Change-Id: I32b9e8dbc6e28a045ac8ef159afe1cf74b7ac6fb

cmp_version compares a as less than b. self.assertTrue(agent.cmp_version('1.2.3.4', '1.2.3.5') < 0) def test_greater_than(self): # Test that cmp_version compares a as greater than b. self.assertTrue(agent.cmp_version('1.2.3.5', '1.2.3.4') > 0) def test_equal(self): # Test that cmp_version compares a as equal to b. self.assertTrue(agent.cmp_version('1.2.3.4', '1.2.3.4') == 0) def test_non_lexical(self): # Test that cmp_version compares non-lexically. self.assertTrue(agent.cmp_version('1.2.3.10', '1.2.3.4') > 0) def test_length(self): # Test that cmp_version compares by length as last resort. self.assertTrue(agent.cmp_version('1.2.3', '1.2.3.4') < 0) class CallAgentTestCase(AgentTestCaseBase): def test_get_vm_rec(self): session = mock.Mock() session.call_xenapi.return_value = "rec" self.assertEqual("rec", agent._get_vm_rec(session, "vm_ref")) session.call_xenapi.assert_called_once_with("VM.get_record", "vm_ref") @mock.patch.object(uuid, "uuid4") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_get_vm_rec") def test_call_agent_success(self, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): session = mock.Mock() instance = {"uuid": "fake"} addl_args = {"foo": "bar"} mock_get_vm_rec.return_value = {'domid': '42'} mock_uuid.return_value = 1 session.call_plugin.return_value = {'returncode': '4', 'message': "asdf\\r\\n"} self.assertEqual("asdf", agent._call_agent(session, instance, "vm_ref", "method", addl_args, timeout=300, success_codes=['0', '4'])) mock_get_vm_rec.assert_called_once_with(session, "vm_ref") expected_args = { 'id': '1', 'dom_id': '42', 'timeout': '300', } expected_args.update(addl_args) session.call_plugin.assert_called_once_with("agent", "method", expected_args) def _call_agent_setup(self, session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid, returncode='0', success_codes=None, exception=None): session.XenAPI.Failure = xenapi_fake.Failure instance = {"uuid": "fake"} mock_get_vm_rec.return_value = {'domid': '42'} mock_uuid.return_value = 1 if exception: session.call_plugin.side_effect = exception else: session.call_plugin.return_value = {'returncode': returncode, 'message': "asdf\\r\\n"} return agent._call_agent(session, instance, "vm_ref", "method", success_codes=success_codes) def _assert_agent_called(self, session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): mock_get_vm_rec.assert_called_once_with(session, "vm_ref") expected_args = { 'id': '1', 'dom_id': '42', 'timeout': '30', } session.call_plugin.assert_called_once_with("agent", "method", expected_args) @mock.patch.object(uuid, "uuid4") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_get_vm_rec") def test_call_agent_works_with_defaults(self, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): session = mock.Mock() self._call_agent_setup(session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid) self._assert_agent_called(session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid) @mock.patch.object(uuid, "uuid4") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_get_vm_rec") def test_call_agent_fails_with_timeout(self, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): session = mock.Mock() self.assertRaises(exception.AgentTimeout, self._call_agent_setup, session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid, exception=xenapi_fake.Failure(["TIMEOUT:fake"])) self._assert_agent_called(session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid) @mock.patch.object(uuid, "uuid4") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_get_vm_rec") def test_call_agent_fails_with_not_implemented(self, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): session = mock.Mock() self.assertRaises(exception.AgentNotImplemented, self._call_agent_setup, session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid, exception=xenapi_fake.Failure(["NOT IMPLEMENTED:"])) self._assert_agent_called(session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid) @mock.patch.object(uuid, "uuid4") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_get_vm_rec") def test_call_agent_fails_with_other_error(self, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): session = mock.Mock() self.assertRaises(exception.AgentError, self._call_agent_setup, session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid, exception=xenapi_fake.Failure(["asdf"])) self._assert_agent_called(session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid) @mock.patch.object(uuid, "uuid4") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_get_vm_rec") def test_call_agent_fails_with_returned_error(self, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid): session = mock.Mock() self.assertRaises(exception.AgentError, self._call_agent_setup, session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid, returncode='42') self._assert_agent_called(session, mock_get_vm_rec, mock_uuid) @mock.patch.object(agent.XenAPIBasedAgent, "_add_instance_fault") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_call_agent") def test_agent_call_agent_swallows_error(self, mock_call_agent, mock_add_instance_fault): fake_error = exception.AgentError(method="bob") mock_call_agent.side_effect = fake_error instance = _get_fake_instance() agent = self._create_agent(instance) agent._call_agent("bob") mock_call_agent.assert_called_once_with(agent.session, agent.instance, agent.vm_ref, "bob", None, None, None) mock_add_instance_fault.assert_called_once_with(fake_error, mock.ANY) @mock.patch.object(agent.XenAPIBasedAgent, "_add_instance_fault") @mock.patch.object(agent, "_call_agent") def test_agent_call_agent_throws_error(self, mock_call_agent, mock_add_instance_fault): fake_error = exception.AgentError(method="bob") mock_call_agent.side_effect = fake_error instance = _get_fake_instance() agent = self._create_agent(instance) self.assertRaises(exception.AgentError, agent._call_agent, "bob", ignore_errors=False) mock_call_agent.assert_called_once_with(agent.session, agent.instance, agent.vm_ref, "bob", None, None, None) self.assertFalse(mock_add_instance_fault.called)

commit_message:
A nicer calling convention for object instantiation

This patch makes the base object constructor take some arguments
to streamline the process of creating a new object. By taking
a context and an optional set of keyword args, we can reduce
the lines of code required to create an object from many to, often,
one.

Change-Id: Id85c70d04af500ece48e9c93ee55a8e3d579299d

commit_message:
Check for None when cleaning PCI dev usage

The PCI manager needs to check for instance UUIDs mapped to
None when cleaning up it's internal claims/allocations maps.

Also adds a check so the claims dict doesn't map to None in
the first place.  There was already a check like this when
setting a value in the allocations dict.

Closes-Bug: #1238374

Change-Id: I7ac010f7d50ad85c145e536cfd48e07c8f4602d3

deleted_lines: for dev in self.claims.pop(uuid): self._free_device(dev) for dev in self.allocations.pop(uuid): self._free_device(dev)

commit_message:
Cells: Fix instance deletes

A regression was introduced with object conversion that caused all
instances to be locally deleted in the API cell when cells is enabled.
This would happen before the child cell was told to delete the instance.

Additionally, if an instance record was created in a child cell but
failed to schedule to a host in such a way that the API cell has
no knowledge of the 'host', the instance would be deleted in the API
cell only.

Also, it appears that we would cast deletes to child cells twice due to
logic duplicated in cells_api.py that exists in api.py.

Closes-Bug: #1240247

Change-Id: I94cfddd9cef2d63b2cb31c0f2dae8e211a4418d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/48/51948/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

In this latter # case, just commit the reservation until we can handle # quotas a bit better with cells. if self.cell_type != 'api': self._local_delete(context, instance, bdms, delete_type, cb)

commit_message:
Add CIDR field type

This field type provides a strong verification that a value
assigned to a CIDR field is valid. This will be used for
the SecurityGroupRuleObject to follow.

Related to blueprint compute-api-objects

Change-Id: Ib62a515eea563da3107a3aed516a51d0ff55ba35
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/51747/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class CIDR(FieldType): def coerce(self, obj, attr, value): try: network, length = value.split('/') except (ValueError, AttributeError): raise ValueError(_('CIDR "%(cidr)s" is not in proper form'), cidr=value) try: network = netaddr.IPAddress(network) except netaddr.AddrFormatError: raise ValueError(_('Network "%(network)s is not valid'), network=network) try: length = int(length) except ValueError: raise ValueError(_('Netmask length "%(length)s" is not valid'), length=length) if ((network.version == 4 and length > 32) or (network.version == 6 and length > 128)): raise ValueError(_('Netmask length "%(length)s" is not valid ' 'for IPv%(version)i address'), length=length, version=network.version) return value

commit_message:
Remove compute_api_class config option

This option was deprecated in Havana and can now be removed.  Its only
use was for changing out the API class if cells was in use.
Technically, it used to be possible to configure an arbitrary compute
API class.  However, that would have been an unsupported setup, and has
been completely broken since 9f902c7e17249cf5af1504f31d80c0247a02fe20
anyway.

As a part of this change, the cell_type configuration option needed a
default value.  I set it to 'compute'.  My reasoning was that you would
have more compute cells than API cells, so might as well set it to the
more common case.

Change-Id: I5ec44f84267a700da16b350e686eee886e0d1183

commit_message:
Flattened chapter structure.

Added basic Manage Services chapter, and placed Identity and Compute sections inside. Redid Compute section header to match. Removed installation instructions (user should already have installed).

Change-Id: Iffb15804ea7c3b6e6ebed526fdd17c4e125184a8

commit_message:
Remove aggregate metadata methods from conductor and virtapi

The aggregate_metadata_add() and aggregate_metadata_remove()
methods are no longer needed in virtapi and conductor. This
patch removes them from the former and deprecates them in the
latter. Also, aggregate_get_by_host() is no longer needed in
virtapi, so remove it from there.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: Ia057dcc43c555187a4a1466a9e748b978c46d4a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/67/50467/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix cleanup ordering in moxstubout fixture
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-16 17:50:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/43497db095944b80e9affe6052e295e43383262d', 'message': 'Fix cleanup ordering in moxstubout fixture

The ordering of fixture cleanup calls is very important in preventing test
interactions.

Originally, Nova got this ordering wrong, so we had to fix it here:

    https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/4e560d49d4a8d08341dae6df5e123e1be1b3c779

Unfortunately, when the fixture was added to Oslo, it was added using the
original incorrect ordering, not the revised, correct ordering.

This caused Nova to regress and suffer the same sporadic test failures we had
when fixing the original Nova bug.

A recent commit

    https://github.com/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/f4a485530ebd123cdb80b8b8a378ff9847b2a5d7

commit_message:
Fix cleanup ordering in moxstubout fixture

The ordering of fixture cleanup calls is very important in preventing test
interactions.

Originally, Nova got this ordering wrong, so we had to fix it here:

   4e560d49d4a8d08341dae6df5e123e1be1b3c779

Unfortunately, when the fixture was added to Oslo, it was added using the
original, incorrect ordering.

This caused Nova to regress and suffer the same sporadic test failures we had
when fixing the original Nova bug.

A recent commit (f4a485530ebd123cdb80b8b8a378ff9847b2a5d7) attempted to fix
this by sharing stubs between the self.stubs and self.mox.

Unfortunately, this caused other Nova tests to fail
(nova/tests/network/test_manager.py).

The fix is to use the original Nova fixture with the correct cleanup ordering.

Fixes bug 1239898

Change-Id: I0971eacf165667bb060b5cd7ec4f8182d71346e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/74/52174/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import stubout # NOTE(sirp): the order of these cleanup calls is *very* important to # prevent tests from interacting with each other. # # Developers should avoid using mox and stubs at the same time, but if # they must, always STUB BEFORE MOX. self.stubs = stubout.StubOutForTesting() self.addCleanup(self.stubs.UnsetAll) self.addCleanup(self.stubs.SmartUnsetAll)
deleted_lines: # emulate some of the mox stuff, we can't use the metaclass # because it screws with our generators self.stubs = self.mox.stubs

commit_message:
V2 RpcApi should register when db pool is enabled

The rpc api controller registers the public methods of db_api
But, use_tpool is True, the thread pool wrapper's methods are
used which would lead to failures.

Fixes Bug #1221037

Change-Id: Iaba10178c7da1548257e2180658c2dc8ba3e048b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/79/46279/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add storage policy support for the Replicator

Replicator support for Storage Policies

Adds storoge policy awareness to the replicator service so that it
processes all policy rings according to their type.  Thus it also
extends storage policies to include a 'type' element per policy.
The 'type' will default to 'replication' if not specified.  Below
it is specified for example purposes:

[storage-policy:0]
name = chicken
type = replication

Change-Id: I44a103b8a475408b221062050c1ea652bca64702
Implements: swift-ec

For example purposes, 'replication' # is called out explcitly below.#type = replication

commit_message:
Add task state verification

Change-Id: I85abee2a1112ce1b9bb708cb9129f06c794f83b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/07/51407/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PENDING = PENDINGSUCCESS = SUCCESS ## Task state transitions # https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TaskFlow/States_of_Task_and_Flow#Task_States _ALLOWED_TASK_TRANSITIONS = frozenset(( (PENDING, RUNNING), # run it! (RUNNING, SUCCESS), # the task finished successfully (RUNNING, FAILURE), # the task failed (RUNNING, REVERTING), # the task was 'killed while' running # and immediately reverted (FAILURE, REVERTING), # task failed, do cleanup now (SUCCESS, REVERTING), # some other task failed, do cleanup now (REVERTING, REVERTED), # revert done (REVERTING, FAILURE), # revert failed (REVERTED, PENDING), # try again )) # NOTE(harlowja) During RUNNING we allow for 3rd party states to be set, but # those states must *not* conflict with our own states. _ALL_TASK_STATES = ( FAILURE, PENDING, REVERTED, REVERTING, RUNNING, SUCCESS, ) def check_task_transition(old_state, new_state): """Check that task can transition from old_state to new_state. If transition can be performed, it returns True. If transition should be ignored, it returns False. If transition is not valid, it raises InvalidStateException. """ if old_state == new_state: return False pair = (old_state, new_state) if pair in _ALLOWED_TASK_TRANSITIONS: return True # Allow for 3rd party states to be triggered during RUNNING. if old_state == RUNNING: if new_state not in _ALL_TASK_STATES: return True raise exc.InvalidStateException( "Task transition from %s to %s is not allowed" % pair)
deleted_lines: SUCCESS = SUCCESS

commit_message:
Add call to get specific image member

Fixes bug 1233806

Add GET call to get a specific image member. Makes it easier to
check image member status

DocImpact

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/36/49236/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from glance.openstack.common import log as loggingLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def show(self, req, image_id, member_id): """ Returns the membership of the tenant wrt to the image_id specified. :param req: the Request object coming from the wsgi layer :param image_id: The image identifier :retval The response body is a mapping of the following form:: {'member_id': <MEMBER>, 'image_id': <IMAGE>, 'status': <MEMBER_STATUS> 'created_at': .., 'updated_at': ..} """ image_repo = self.gateway.get_repo(req.context) try: image = image_repo.get(image_id) member_repo = image.get_member_repo() member = member_repo.get(member_id) return member except exception.NotFound: msg = _("Member %s not found for image %s" % (member_id, image_id)) LOG.warn(msg) raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=msg) except exception.Forbidden: msg = _("Member %s not found for image %s" % (member_id, image_id)) LOG.warn(msg) raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=msg) def show(self, response, image_member): image_member_view = {} image_member_view = self._format_image_member(image_member) totalview['schema'] = '/v2/schemas/member' body = json.dumps(totalview, ensure_ascii=False) response.unicode_body = unicode(body) response.content_type = 'application/json'

commit_message:
Enable tasks data model and table for async worker

Add tasks data model and table for async worker to
store the tasks data persistently.

Partially implement blueprint async-glance-workers

Change-Id: I2b2d70295da4905bf75cffc2b2eadec174d1abfc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/17/42817/26 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _check_028(self, engine, data): table = "tasks" index_type = ('ix_tasks_type', ['type']) index_status = ('ix_tasks_status', ['status']) meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData() meta.bind = engine new_table = sqlalchemy.Table(table, meta, autoload=True) index_data = [(idx.name, idx.columns.keys()) for idx in new_table.indexes] self.assertIn(index_type, index_data) self.assertIn(index_status, index_data)

subject: Add Storage Policy Support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-01 23:31:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/f1638c85c82e39cf767e6dc82dc4bbdf63744348', 'message': 'Add general multi-ring support

The basic idea here is to replace the use of a single object ring in the Application
class with a list of object rings.  The list includes not only the Ring object itself
but the policy name assocaited with it, the filename for the .gz and any other meta
data associated with the policy that may be needed.

The list of object rings is based off of info in the swift.conf file parsed at wsgi
application init time.  The format of the sections in the .conf file is self-
explanatory and a list is exported from utils.py that has all of the info except
for the Ring addresses; the rings are instantiated when Application() is instantiated
and then Application.object.nodes is updated with the addresses.  There is a new
accessor method called Application.get_object_ring() that returns the Ring address
based on the policy passed in.  There is basic error handling in both the conf file
parser as well as the accessor function to assure the conf file is formed correctly
and that the defaulr triple-repl ring is returned as default.

This commit focuses only on the Proxy server (storage node services using the obj
rings will be next) and the unit test framework.  No new tests have been added yet
as the number of changes required to support multiple rings in the test framwork
was large.

Ring selection is done at public entry points based on container metadata.  If the
container has the metadata X-Container-Meta_Storage_Policy and there is a match
with the policy name provided and one parsed from swift.conf, that ring will be
used.  If not then triple-repl will be the default.  The new container metadata
policy cannot be changed, if an attempt is made to change it a conflict error
will be returned.  Migrating data from one policy to another means copying it
from one container to another manually.

The following highlights the major changes in thsi commit:

* objecr ring address stored in Request class to support different rings for
concurrent IOs (there is only one instance of the Application class)
* swift.conf file parser support for storage policies
* container update to support immutable storage policy metadata
* a few misc function parm changes to enable passing of ring info
* use of ring based on container metadata in objController public functions
* use of specific ring for internally generated requests
* Application class changes to support new element - a list of dict items
representing the supported storage policies and Ring addresses
* large number of changes to unit test framework to support multiple rings
but no new capabilities specifically geared at testing multiple rings

Change-Id: I53bcad1dc724596c5c4ec8a30d5cf50ebe7f1b7d
Implements:  blueprint ec-proxy-work
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-08-02 20:58:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/7a7f16e083bd1ae3b032eeb14665370600c6b88b', 'message': 'Add general multi-ring support

The basic idea here is to replace the use of a single object ring in the Application
class with a list of object rings.  The list includes not only the Ring object itself
but the policy name assocaited with it, the filename for the .gz and any other meta
data associated with the policy that may be needed.

The list of object rings is based off of info in the swift.conf file parsed at wsgi
application init time.  The format of the sections in the .conf file is self-
explanatory and a list is exported from utils.py that has all of the info except
for the Ring addresses; the rings are instantiated when Application() is instantiated
and then Application.object.nodes is updated with the addresses.  There is a new
accessor method called Application.get_object_ring() that returns the Ring address
based on the policy passed in.  There is basic error handling in both the conf file
parser as well as the accessor function to assure the conf file is formed correctly
and that the defaulr triple-repl ring is returned as default (even if no policy is
defined in the swift.conf file)

This commit focuses only on the Proxy server (storage node services using the obj
rings will be next) and the unit test framework.  No new tests have been added yet
as the number of changes required to support multiple rings in the test framwork
was large.

Ring selection is done at public entry points based on container metadata.  If the
container has the metadata X-Container-Meta_Storage_Policy and there is a match
with the policy name provided and one parsed from swift.conf, that ring will be
used.  If not then triple-repl will be the default.  The new container metadata
policy cannot be changed, if an attempt is made to change it a conflict error
will be returned.  Migrating data from one policy to another means copying it
from one container to another manually.

The following highlights the major changes in thsi commit:

* objecr ring address stored in Request class to support different rings for
concurrent IOs (there is only one instance of the Application class)
* swift.conf file parser support for storage policies
* container update to support immutable storage policy metadata
* a few misc function parm changes to enable passing of ring info
* use of ring based on container metadata in objController public functions
* use of specific ring for internally generated requests
* Application class changes to support new element - a list of dict items
representing the supported storage policies and Ring addresses
* large number of changes to unit test framework to support multiple rings
but no new capabilities specifically geared at testing multiple rings

Change-Id: I53bcad1dc724596c5c4ec8a30d5cf50ebe7f1b7d
Implements:  blueprint ec-proxy-work

class with a collection of object rings. The collection includes not only the Ring
object itself but the policy name assocaited with it, the filename for the .gz and
any other meta data associated with the policy that may be needed.

The policy collection is based off of info in the swift.conf file parsed at wsgi
application init time. The format of the sections in the .conf file is covered
below and accessed via get_storage_policies() that has all of the info except
for the Ring addresses; the rings are instantiated when Application() is instantiated
and then Application.object.nodes is updated with the addresses. There is a new
accessor method called Application.get_object_ring() that returns the Ring address
based on the policy passed in. There is basic error handling in both the conf file
parser as well as the accessor functions to assure the conf file is formed correctly.

swift.conf format:

	[storage-policy:0]
	name = chicken

	[storage-policy:1]
	name = turkey
	default = yes

	[storage-policy:2]
	name = gravy
	ec-scheme:14:10

With the above format:

- policy 0 will always be used for access to existing containers w/o the policy specified.
The ring name for polic 0 is always 'object' assuring backwards compatiblity.  The parser
will always create a policy 0 even if not specified
- the policy with 'default=yes' is the one used for new container creation and allows the
admin to specify which policy is used without forcing the application to add the metadata.
- use of 'ec-scheme' implies that the associated ring is built for erasure code and
includes the ec scheme parameter.  A policy w/o any other tag like this implies replication
using where the # of copies is determined by how the ring was built

This commit focuses only on the Proxy server (storage node services using the obj
rings will be next) and the unit test framework. No new tests have been added yet
as the number of changes required to support multiple rings in the test framwork
was large.

Ring selection is done at public entry points based on container metadata. If the
container has the metadata X-Container-Storage-Policy and there is a match
with the policy name provided and one parsed from swift.conf, that ring will be
used. If not then decisions are made per description of swift.conf sectiosn above.

The container metadata policy cannot be changed, if an attempt is made to change it a c
onflict error will be returned. An attempt to create a container with a policy not defined
results in a bad reqeust error.  Migrating data from one policy to another means copying it
from one container to another manually.

The following highlights the major changes in this commit:

* swift.conf file parser support for storage policies
* container update to support immutable storage policy metadata
* a few misc function parm changes to enable passing of ring info
* use of ring based on container metadata in objController public functions
* large number of changes to unit test framework to support multiple rings
but no new capabilities specifically geared at testing multiple rings

Change-Id: I53bcad1dc724596c5c4ec8a30d5cf50ebe7f1b7d
Implements:  blueprint ec-proxy-work

"}, {'number': 22, 'created': '2013-09-06 22:17:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/299d9a77a7e5c908b33e7695a30176bd5d7c682a', 'message': "Add general multi-ring support

The basic idea here is to replace the use of a single object ring in the Application
class with a collection of object rings. The collection includes not only the Ring
object itself but the policy name assocaited with it, the filename for the .gz and
any other meta data associated with the policy that may be needed.

The policy collection is based off of info in the swift.conf file parsed at wsgi
application init time. The format of the sections in the .conf file is covered
below and accessed via get_storage_policies() that has all of the info except
for the Ring addresses; the rings are instantiated when Application() is instantiated
and then Application.object.nodes is updated with the addresses. There is a new
accessor method called Application.get_object_ring() that returns the Ring address
based on the policy passed in. There is basic error handling in both the conf file
parser as well as the accessor functions to assure the conf file is formed correctly.

swift.conf format:

	[storage-policy:0]
	name = chicken

	[storage-policy:1]
	name = turkey
	default = yes

With the above format:

- policy 0 will always be used for access to existing containers w/o the policy specified.
The ring name for polic 0 is always 'object' assuring backwards compatiblity.  The parser
will always create a policy 0 even if not specified
- the policy with 'default=yes' is the one used for new container creation and allows the
admin to specify which policy is used without forcing the application to add the metadata.
- in the future new elements can be added such as 'ec-scheme' which would imply that the
associated ring is built for erasure code and includes some ec scheme parameters.
A policy w/o any other tag like this implies replication using where the # of copies is
determined by how the ring was built

This commit focuses only on the Proxy server (storage node services using the obj
rings will be next) and the unit test framework. No new tests have been added yet
as the number of changes required to support multiple rings in the test framwork
was large.

Ring selection is done at public entry points based on container metadata. If the
container has the metadata X-Storage-Policy and there is a match with the policy
name provided and one parsed from swift.conf, that ring will be used. If not then
decisions are made per description of swift.conf sectiosn above.  Note that internally
there is a policy index that is used in conjunction with X-Storage-Policy that enables
the cluster admin to both support backwards compatibility as well as choose the
default that is most applicable for their cluster.

The container metadata policy cannot be changed, if an attempt is made to change it a c
onflict error will be returned. An attempt to create a container with a policy not defined
results in a bad reqeust error.  Migrating data from one policy to another means copying it
from one container to another manually.

The following highlights the major changes in this commit:

* swift.conf file parser support for storage policies (new storage_policy.py)
* container update to support immutable storage policy metadata
* a few misc function parm changes to enable passing of ring info
* use of ring based on container metadata in objController public functions
* large number of changes to unit test framework to support multiple rings
but no new capabilities specifically geared at testing multiple rings

Change-Id: I53bcad1dc724596c5c4ec8a30d5cf50ebe7f1b7d
Implements:  blueprint ec-proxy-work

Ring selection is done at public entry points based on container metadata. If the
container has the metadata X-Storage-Policy and there is a match with the policy
name provided and one parsed from swift.conf, that ring will be used. If not then
decisions are made per description of swift.conf sectiosn above.  Note that internally
there is a policy index that is used in conjunction with X-Storage-Policy that enables
the cluster admin to both support backwards compatibility as well as choose the
default that is most applicable for their cluster.  The internal metadata stored in
containers is called X-Storage-Policy-Index.

The container metadata policy cannot be changed, if an attempt is made to change it a c
onflict error will be returned. An attempt to create a container with a policy not defined
results in a bad reqeust error.  Migrating data from one policy to another means copying it
from one container to another manually.

The following highlights the major changes in this commit:

* swift.conf file parser support for storage policies (new storage_policy.py)
* container update to support immutable storage policy metadata
* a few misc function parm changes to enable passing of ring info
* use of ring based on container metadata in objController public functions
* large number of changes to unit test framework to support multiple rings
but no new capabilities specifically geared at testing multiple rings
* unit tests covering all new functinality

Change-Id: I53bcad1dc724596c5c4ec8a30d5cf50ebe7f1b7d
Implements:  blueprint ec-proxy-work

	name = turkey
	default = yes

commit_message:
Add Storage Policy Support

The basic idea here is to replace the use of a single object ring in the Application
class with a collection of object rings. The collection includes not only the Ring
object itself but the policy name assocaited with it, the filename for the .gz and
any other meta data associated with the policy that may be needed.  When containers
are created, a policy (thus a specific obj ring) is selected allowing apps to
specify policy at container creation time and leverage policies simply by using
different containers for object operations.

The policy collection is based off of info in the swift.conf file parsed at wsgi
application init time. The format of the sections in the .conf file is covered
below and accessed via get__policies() that has all of the info except
for the Ring addresses; the rings are instantiated "just in time" when the App
method get_object_ring() is inoked for the first time per policy. There is basic
error handling in both the conf file parser as well as the accessor functions to
assure the conf file is formed correctly.

swift.conf format:

	[storage-policy:0]
	name = chicken

	[storage-policy:1]
	name = turkey
	default = yes

With the above format:

- policy 0 will always be used for access to existing containers w/o the policy specified.
The ring name for polic 0 is always 'object' assuring backwards compatiblity.  The parser
will always create a policy 0 even if not specified
- the policy with 'default=yes' is the one used for new container creation and allows the
admin to specify which policy is used without forcing the application to add the metadata.
- in the future new elements can be added such as 'ec-scheme' which would imply that the
associated ring is built for erasure code and includes some ec scheme parameters.
A policy w/o any other tag like this implies replication using where the # of copies is
determined by how the ring was built

This commit focuses only on the Proxy server (storage node services using the obj
rings will be next) and the unit test framework changes and new unit tests.

Ring selection is done at public entry points based on container metadata. If the
container has the metadata X-Storage-Policy and there is a match with the policy
name provided and one parsed from swift.conf, that ring will be used. If not then
decisions are made per description of swift.conf sections above.  Note that internally
there is a policy index that is used in conjunction with X-Storage-Policy that enables
the cluster admin to both support backwards compatibility as well as choose the
default that is most applicable for their cluster.  The internal metadata stored in
containers is called X-Storage-Policy-Index.

The container metadata policy cannot be changed, if an attempt is made to change it a c
onflict error will be returned. An attempt to create a container with a policy not defined
results in a bad reqeust error.  Migrating data from one policy to another means copying it
from one container to another manually.

The following highlights the major changes in this commit:

* swift.conf file parser support for storage policies (new storage_policy.py)
* container update to support immutable storage policy metadata
* a few misc function parm changes to enable passing of ring info
* use of ring based on container metadata in objController public functions
* large number of changes to unit test framework to support multiple rings
but no new capabilities specifically geared at testing multiple rings
* unit tests covering all new functinality

Storage Node services to support Storage Polciies are not included here.

Change-Id: I53bcad1dc724596c5c4ec8a30d5cf50ebe7f1b7d
Implements:  blueprint ec-proxy-work
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/39/39839/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """ Choose the storage policy based on container metadata and if not specified use the default """ if 'storage-policy' not in info.get('meta', {}): info['meta']['storage-policy'] = 'triple-repl'

commit_message:
Adds documentation for building the v3 API docs

Change-Id: Ie844fce10d15b7b0e0052b85996f742b8f118d84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/identity-api refs/changes/50/52150/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/sh # Converts the Markdown source into DocBook format suitable for using # in the Maven build process. # # Adapted from: # https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Documentation/Builds#Markdown_and_DocBook SOURCES=`ls src/markdown/*.md` FILENAME=identity-api-v3 DIRPATH=. XSL=/usr/share/xml/docbook/stylesheet/docbook5/db4-upgrade.xsl pandoc -f markdown -t docbook -s $SOURCES | \ xsltproc -o - $XSL - | \ xmllint --format -| \ sed -e "s,<article,<chapter xml:id=\"$FILENAME\"," | \ sed -e 's,</article>,</chapter>,' > ${DIRPATH}/$FILENAME.xml

subject: xenapi: Speedup vm_util and vmops tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-14 23:16:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c290036e27fd142c0b57e6c7653492652e44cdba', 'message': 'xenapi: Speedup vm_util and vmops tests

* Uses NODBTestCase in more places

* Also, adds VMUtilsTestBase so that all new test cases in test_vm_utils will,
by default, not use the database.

Speed up observed from running:

nosetests nova/tests/virt/xenapi/test_vm_utils.py
          nova/tests/virt/xenapi/test_vmops.py

BEFORE: Ran 113 tests in 7.674s

commit_message:
xenapi: Speedup vm_util and vmops tests

* Uses NODBTestCase in more places

* Also, adds VMUtilsTestBase so that all new test cases in test_vm_utils will,
by default, not use the database.

Speed up observed from running:

nosetests nova/tests/virt/xenapi/test_vm_utils.py
          nova/tests/virt/xenapi/test_vmops.py

BEFORE: Ran 113 tests in 7.674s
AFTER: Ran 113 tests in 1.873s

Change-Id: Id05ecac90201fba27cbae7480d3119cacd92ec24

subject: Fix IP recycling on exhausted pool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-16 14:40:40.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/test_db_plugin.py', 'neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/9808cac073777ae375074121f9eab15403f1a856', 'message': "Fix IP recycling on exhausted pool

When recycling an IP, allocation pools are loaded with an inner
join with ip avaiblity ranges. However, if the pool is exhausted,
there will be no availability ranges and the query will return
no results because of the inner join. It will therefore be
impossible to reuse IP addresses once the pool has been exhausted.

This patch tries to reload allocation pools without joining on
IP avaiability ranges if the first query did not return any result.
Replacing an inner join with an outer join will not be possible
as postgresql backend does not support 'SELECT ... FOR UPDATE' with
outer joins (for more info see bug 1215350).

The patch also contains unit tests for verifying IP are recycled
correctly even when the pool is exhausted.

Bug 1240353

Change-Id: I87f274bd759cb47be77717f0760d3704f9f34ade
(cherry picked from commit 72af3cef2a476b7f1f7d109d1bd37cd50a6f560e)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix IP recycling on exhausted pool

When recycling an IP, allocation pools are loaded with an inner
join with ip avaiblity ranges. However, if the pool is exhausted,
there will be no availability ranges and the query will return
no results because of the inner join. It will therefore be
impossible to reuse IP addresses once the pool has been exhausted.

This patch tries to reload allocation pools without joining on
IP avaiability ranges if the first query did not return any result.
Replacing an inner join with an outer join will not be possible
as postgresql backend does not support 'SELECT ... FOR UPDATE' with
outer joins (for more info see bug 1215350).

The patch also contains unit tests for verifying IP are recycled
correctly even when the pool is exhausted.

Bug 1240353

Change-Id: I87f274bd759cb47be77717f0760d3704f9f34ade
(cherry picked from commit 72af3cef2a476b7f1f7d109d1bd37cd50a6f560e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/23/52123/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import itertools # If there are no available ranges the previous query will return no # results as it uses an inner join to avoid errors with the postgresql # backend (see lp bug 1215350). In this case IP allocation pools must # be loaded with a different query, which does not require lock for # update as the allocation pools for a subnet are immutable. # The 2nd query will be executed only if the first yields no results unlocked_allocation_pools = (context.session.query( models_v2.IPAllocationPool).filter_by(subnet_id=subnet_id)) for allocation_pool in itertools.chain(allocation_pools, unlocked_allocation_pools): allocation_pool['first_ip'], allocation_pool['last_ip']) LOG.debug(_("All IPs from subnet %(subnet_id)s (%(cidr)s) "
deleted_lines: for allocation_pool in allocation_pools: allocation_pool['first_ip'], allocation_pool['last_ip']) LOG.debug(_("All IP's from subnet %(subnet_id)s (%(cidr)s) "

commit_message:
use proxy mode on vxlan interface only when l2-population is activated

the proxy mode was set by default on every vxlan interfaces
which leads to inaccessibility between VM that are not hosted
on the same host in a vxlan network

Closes-Bug: #1237082

Change-Id: I34028ee0bdfdccda61c6a29f58759259da060b68
(cherry picked from commit 345f8e1fdc65e0cf23369488d4318c0755d6b65d)

commit_message:
'Persist' __getattr__ results

This patch adds a new decorator that helps creating 'cachable'
__getattr__ methods. The decorator sets the returned value as an
attribute of the instance.

The patch also decorates `Pipeline`'s __getattr__ method

Implements blueprint storage-pipeline

Change-Id: I6b052d536d5c6e6edaeec884b3c4a0e8703b1036

some quick pointers to the distribution start pages.

commit_message:
Fix to properly log when we release a semaphore

add a try/finally to ensure the LOG.debug is printed
properly. Currently the debug message is never executed

Change-Id: Ifa6acf17cf4734a1367fb7ef844483f7b8b94741
Related-Bug: 1235437

commit_message:
Fix Huawei HVS driver AttributeError

This patch checks the iSCSI port info and raises an exception
if it can not get the port info from the configuration.

Closes-bug: #1237185
Change-Id: I341ccbe77abd25421e5ee0b2d07ace3759fbccef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/39/50539/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: lunsetinfo = {'LUNType': 'Thin', if not iscsi_port_info: msg = (_('_get_iscsi_port_info: Failed to get iscsi port info ' 'through config IP %(ip)s, please check config file.') % {'ip': ip}) LOG.error(msg) raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) if newstr[0] == 'A': ctr = "0" elif newstr[0] == 'B': ctr = "1" interface = '0' + newstr[1] port = '0' + newstr[3] iqn_suffix = ctr + '02' + interface + port for i in range(0, len(iqn_suffix)): if iqn_suffix[i] != '0': iqn_suffix = iqn_suffix[i:] break iqn = iqn_prefix + ':' + iqn_suffix + ':' + iscsiip LOG.debug(_('_get_tgt_iqn: iSCSI target iqn is %s') % iqn) return iqn
deleted_lines: lunsetinfo = {'LUNType': 'Thick', break LOG.debug(_('request ip info is %s.') % ip_info) LOG.debug(_('new str info is %s.') % newstr) if ip_info: if newstr[0] == 'A': ctr = "0" elif newstr[0] == 'B': ctr = "1" interface = '0' + newstr[1] port = '0' + newstr[3] iqn_suffix = ctr + '02' + interface + port for i in range(0, len(iqn_suffix)): if iqn_suffix[i] != '0': iqn_suffix = iqn_suffix[i:] break iqn = iqn_prefix + ':' + iqn_suffix + ':' + iscsiip LOG.debug(_('_get_tgt_iqn: iSCSI target iqn is %s') % iqn) return iqn else: return None

commit_message:
Orchestration autoscaling improve status polling

This change includes the following improvements to the
autoscaling test:
- On stack create status timeout, override the error status so
  that FAILED stacks fail fast
- Improve the error message in assertScale
- Delete the stack at the end of the scenario, and confirm the delete
  succeeded

Change-Id: Ia220e3a2b422472ac7c6d29f9a5a61bd7c4987c3

deleted_lines: # -*- encoding: utf-8 -*- # # Copyright  2012 New Dream Network, LLC (DreamHost) # # Author: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Base class for plugin loader. """ from stevedore import enabled from ironic.openstack.common import log LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) def should_use_extension(namespace, ext, enabled_names): """Return boolean indicating whether the extension should be used. Tests the extension against a couple of criteria to see whether it should be used, logs the reason it is not used if not, and then returns the result. """ if ext.name not in enabled_names: LOG.debug( '%s extension %r disabled through configuration setting', namespace, ext.name, ) return False if not ext.obj.is_enabled(): LOG.debug( '%s extension %r reported that it is disabled', namespace, ext.name, ) return False LOG.debug('using %s extension %r', namespace, ext.name) return True class ActivatedExtensionManager(enabled.EnabledExtensionManager): """Loads extensions based on a configurable set that should be disabled and asking each one if it should be active or not. """ def __init__(self, namespace, enabled_names, invoke_on_load=True, invoke_args=(), invoke_kwds={}): def local_check_func(ext): return should_use_extension(namespace, ext, enabled_names) super(ActivatedExtensionManager, self).__init__( namespace=namespace, check_func=local_check_func, invoke_on_load=invoke_on_load, invoke_args=invoke_args, invoke_kwds=invoke_kwds, )

when driver_info is changed.

subject: Fix the image name of a shelved server
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-09-30 04:53:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1b778612a57971097f2d996d538b62506b91b9ae', 'message': 'Fix the image name of a shelved server

The shelve feature powers a server off, and creates a snapshot of the
server. The snapshot image name is "instance-XXXXXXXXX-shelved" and it
doesn't contain a server name like the following:

  $ nova list
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | ID | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks         |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | .. | vm01 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.5 |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  $ nova shelve vm01
  $ nova image-list
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name                            | Status | Server |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | instance-00000004-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  $

This patch changes the name to "<server name>-shelved", so that user
can know what snapshot more easily:

  $ nova image-list
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name               | Status | Server |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | vm01-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  $

Note: "nova shelve" command is review in progress.
      (Ic2ad1bb537efb40a3155e9f3c7b63e09e82be7f1)

Fixes bug #1232991

Change-Id: Idc73658e29cb77dfcc8b046535a36affc1831605
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-09-30 05:14:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/512c6722336a6ebb9db3dbab0595f4935e18febc', 'message': 'Fix the image name of a shelved server

The shelve feature powers a server off, and creates a snapshot of the
server. The snapshot image name is "instance-XXXXXXXXX-shelved" and it
doesn't contain a server name like the following:

  $ nova list
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | ID | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks         |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | .. | vm01 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.5 |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  $ nova shelve vm01
  $ nova image-list
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name                            | Status | Server |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | instance-00000004-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  $

This patch changes the name to "<server name>-shelved", so that user
can know the server name of a shelved image more easily:

  $ nova image-list
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name               | Status | Server |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | vm01-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  $

Note: "nova shelve" command is review in progress.
      (Ic2ad1bb537efb40a3155e9f3c7b63e09e82be7f1)

Fixes bug #1232991

commit_message:
Fix the image name of a shelved server

The shelve feature powers a server off, and creates a snapshot of the
server. The snapshot image name is "instance-XXXXXXXXX-shelved" and it
doesn't contain a server name like the following:

  $ nova list
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | ID | Name | Status | Task State | Power State | Networks         |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  | .. | vm01 | ACTIVE | None       | Running     | private=10.0.0.5 |
  +----+------+--------+------------+-------------+------------------+
  $ nova shelve vm01
  $ nova image-list
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name                            | Status | Server |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | instance-00000004-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+---------------------------------+--------+--------+
  $

"instance-XXXXXXXXX" is OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:instance_name, and a non-admin
cannot see it.

This patch changes the name to "<server name>-shelved", so that a non-
admin user can know the server name of a shelved image:

  $ nova image-list
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | ID | Name               | Status | Server |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  | .. | vm01-shelved       | ACTIVE | ..     |
  +----+--------------------+--------+--------+
  $

Closes-Bug: 1232991

Change-Id: Idc73658e29cb77dfcc8b046535a36affc1831605
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/86/48886/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: name = '%s-shelved' % instance['display_name']
deleted_lines: name = '%s-shelved' % instance['name']

commit_message:
Disable lazy gettext

This change disables lazy gettext functionality in Keystone,
due to problems with character encoding and logging
detailed in bug 1225099.

It is part of a series of commits across all projects with
lazy gettext enabled.

Change-Id: Ia934a7df9386baf6ae8eb9ff48c24386c47ecd23
Partial-bug: 1225099
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/20/52120/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: gettextutils.install('keystone')
deleted_lines: # # Configure gettextutils for deferred translation of messages # so that error messages in responses can be translated according to the # Accept-Language in the request rather than the Keystone server locale. gettextutils.install('keystone', lazy=True)

commit_message:
add some negative tests for tenant

making a separate test_tenant_negative.py,and move the exist negative
tests over to it,and add some negative tests for in it.

- test_update_non_existent_tenant
- test_tenant_update_by_unauthorized_user
- test_tenant_update_request_without_token

Change-Id: Id0d15d312c96a3f8a244d5e08414623e3c15013a

commit_message:
Update Cisco N1KV plugin to VSM REST api calls

Modify the existing REST calls from the plugin to VSM to update the
attributes and use UUIDs as index, instead of string names, for all
the resources.

Change-Id: Icb4950ea7c6f036e9a25ee79e3f5fe30d40f47de
Closes-Bug: 1233802

commit_message:
Adds test_update_all_metadata_field_not_included negative test

Adds test_update_all_metadata_field_not_included negative test
which checks a BadRequest is returned when attempting to
set the server metadata and not include the metadata field

Collapses all of the negative tests into one testcase as they
should not have any side effects and it will slightly reduce
setup overhead.

Change-Id: Iab221d23e896fb22bbe351bb20c0378ebaa60add
Closes-Bug: 1131536

subject: Fix IP recycling on exhausted pool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-16 10:19:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e20c61c192366ccd7f4499ebc7c3ccbdd4327d11', 'message': "Fix IP recycling on exhausted pool

When recycling an IP, allocation pools are loaded with an inner
join with ip avaiblity ranges. However, if the pool is exhausted,
there will be no availability ranges and the query will return
no results because of the inner join. It will therefore be
impossible to reuse IP addresses once the pool has been exhausted.

This patch tries to reload allocation pools without joining on
IP avaiability ranges if the first query did not return any result.
Replacing an inner join with an outer join will not be possible
as postgresql backend does not support 'SELECT ... FOR UPDATE' with
outer joins (for more info see bug 1215350).

The patch also contains unit tests for verifying IP are recycled
correctly even when the pool is exhausted.

Bug 1240353

commit_message:
Fix IP recycling on exhausted pool

When recycling an IP, allocation pools are loaded with an inner
join with ip avaiblity ranges. However, if the pool is exhausted,
there will be no availability ranges and the query will return
no results because of the inner join. It will therefore be
impossible to reuse IP addresses once the pool has been exhausted.

This patch tries to reload allocation pools without joining on
IP avaiability ranges if the first query did not return any result.
Replacing an inner join with an outer join will not be possible
as postgresql backend does not support 'SELECT ... FOR UPDATE' with
outer joins (for more info see bug 1215350).

The patch also contains unit tests for verifying IP are recycled
correctly even when the pool is exhausted.

Bug 1240353

Change-Id: I87f274bd759cb47be77717f0760d3704f9f34ade
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/50/52050/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

shotgun.driver.fabric.api.settings.assert_called_with( host_string="remote", timeout=2, warn_only=True) driver = shotgun.driver.Driver({}, None) driver.get(path, target_path) shotgun.driver.execute.assert_any_call( "mkdir -p %s" % os.path.dirname(target_path)) shotgun.driver.execute.assert_any_call( "cp -r %s %s" % (path, target_path))

commit_message:
use proxy mode on vxlan interface only when l2-population is activated

the proxy mode was set by default on every vxlan interfaces
which leads to inaccessibility between VM that are not hosted
on the same host in a vxlan network

Closes-Bug: #1237082

Change-Id: I34028ee0bdfdccda61c6a29f58759259da060b68

This way we can output multiple formats without reprocessing the data.

subject: Remove ordereddict as a requirement
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-16 10:32:21.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/56c60b6f6a7232425f343f0a09dd0d4e9362b246', 'message': "Remove ordereddict as a requirement

'ordereddict' was added as a potential requirement for Glance.
Glance no longer intends to use 'ordereddict' so this requirement can
be removed.

Thomas Goirand's relevant comment (from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/48475):

  ordereddict will *not* be packaged for Debian or Ubuntu. While it is
  perfectly fine to use ordereddict *from* the integrated Python 2.7 support
  (collections.OrderedDict), since both Sid and Precise do not have Python
  2.6 anymore, it isn't correct at all to force the installation of an
  ordereddict package (with pip, apt or otherwise). Please avoid writing
  this as a hard requirement in any OpenStack packages.

The original commit which added 'ordereddict' was:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/46474

Change-Id: Ia88d3536913f62be775558ec20766d27955462f9
"}]
commit_message:
Remove ordereddict as a requirement

'ordereddict' was added as a potential requirement for Glance.
Glance no longer intends to use 'ordereddict' so this requirement can
be removed.

Thomas Goirand's relevant comment (from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/48475):

  ordereddict will *not* be packaged for Debian or Ubuntu. While it is
  perfectly fine to use ordereddict *from* the integrated Python 2.7 support
  (collections.OrderedDict), since both Sid and Precise do not have Python
  2.6 anymore, it isn't correct at all to force the installation of an
  ordereddict package (with pip, apt or otherwise). Please avoid writing
  this as a hard requirement in any OpenStack packages.

The original commit which added 'ordereddict' was:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/46474

Change-Id: Ia88d3536913f62be775558ec20766d27955462f9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/53/52053/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Removes stubs from unit tests

self.stubs in TestCase and BaseTestCase classes use moxstubout
module which uses mox. OpenStack is moving to python 3 which
will not support mox. This patch removes the use of self.stubs
for all the unit test cases.

Change-Id: I0e5aa50edcbb1913c5143bb93efea965f5d5ebfb

commit_message:
Add a neutron parallel job

This commit adds a new run type for running an almost full gate with
neutron enabled, which is tempest-full - ~10 tests, (not counting
neutron skips in the tempest code) and runs it in parallel. In
addition this commit removes the testr-full run, since everything is
already running in parallel by default.

Change-Id: Ib69a30c3d6e87d3d27c0758502046370cfb5adcc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/15/51915/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON" -eq "1" ]] && \ [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_TESTR_FULL" -eq "1" ]] ; then echo "Running pseudo full tempest with neutron in parallel" sudo -H -u tempest tox -eneutron-parallel res=$?
deleted_lines: elif [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_TESTR_FULL" -eq "1" ]]; then echo "Running tempest full test suite with testr" sudo -H -u tempest tox -etestr-full res=$?

commit_message:
Fix huawei HVS driver QoS and Tier issues

Huawei HVS driver supports QOS and Tier functions. User can
open those functions by setting volume type. QOS requires users
to set flow strategy and io priority. Tier requires user to set
distribution policy and transfer strategy.

The current driver limits the QOS strategy to be "Qos-high",
"Qos-normal" and "Qos-low" which is not direct, and just allows
user to set distribution policy: "Tier-high", "Tier-normal" and
"Tier-low".

This patch changes the keys of QOS and Tier and adds transfer
strategy for Tier. Also it checks QOS strategy status when adding
new lun to the strategy.

Closes-bug: #1237268
Change-Id: Ib3daabc3a68da47d81b53857d3080158b5b574f4
(cherry picked from commit Ib3daabc3a68da47d81b53857d3080158b5b574f4)

commit_message:
Add python-six to requirements

missing python-six minimum version from the requirements.txt
set the min version to 1.4.1, without six recent versions of
keystone fail to start with a critical 'module' object has no
attribute 'add_metaclass' error

subject: Fix Huawei drivers to support other host OSs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-10-16 13:52:16.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/huawei_dorado.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/huawei_hvs.py', 'cinder/tests/test_huawei_t_dorado.py', 'cinder/tests/test_huawei_hvs.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/rest_common.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/huawei_utils.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/ssh_common.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/__init__.py', 'cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/huawei_t.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/72edce76707f8547b8b1eb8171a1b265f99974fb', 'message': 'Fix Huawei drivers to support other host OSs

Huawei drivers create Linux hosts by default when attaching volumes.
This patch makes them also support Windows, XenServer, AIX, etc.
The default OS is still Linux if it is not specified.

Users need to configure the host OS types in Huawei XML configuration
file. They need to set the items like this:
<Host OSType="Windows" HostIP="10.10.0.1, 10.10.0.2, ..." />
<Host .../>

When attaching a volume, the driver will get the host IP from nova. We
compare that IP with the IP in "HostIP" to get the corresponding OS type.

Closes-bug: #1229759
Change-Id: I36fd52b97f790f1c68eaf24b6c12e7ef5d16145d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Huawei drivers to support other host OSs

Huawei drivers create Linux hosts by default when attaching volumes.
This patch makes them also support Windows, XenServer, AIX, etc.
The default OS is still Linux if it is not specified.

Users need to configure the host OS types in Huawei XML configuration
file. They need to set the items like this:
<Host OSType="Windows" HostIP="10.10.0.1, 10.10.0.2, ..." />
<Host .../>

When attaching a volume, the driver will get the host IP from nova. We
compare that IP with the IP in "HostIP" to get the corresponding OS type.

Closes-bug: #1229759
Change-Id: I36fd52b97f790f1c68eaf24b6c12e7ef5d16145d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/09/52109/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.volume.drivers.huawei import huawei_utils host_id = self.common.add_host(connector['host'], connector['ip'], root = huawei_utils.parse_xml_file(filename) host_id = self.common.add_host(connector['host'], connector['ip'])
deleted_lines: host_id = self.common.add_host(connector['host'], root = ssh_common.parse_xml_file(filename) host_id = self.common.add_host(connector['host'])

commit_message:
Standardize display name on detail pages

* Standardized overview pages for volume, image and snapshot
as per the instance overview page.

Fixes bug #1207770

Change-Id: I7ae48542f4c8732c92dc4393dbaaea81158d34d6
